instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the related study to estimate the change in body condition score (ABCS) in cows?
Output: Partial least squares regression and a neural network (NN) were the spectral feature processing methods used in the related study to estimate the change in body condition score (ΔBCS) in cows.

instruction: What metric was chosen to estimate ABCS in the related study to estimate the change in body condition score (ABCS) in cows and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to estimate ABCS (change in body condition score) in this study was the mid-infrared spectra of milk. This metric was used in combination with machine learning techniques, specifically partial least squares regression and a neural network, to estimate ABCS. The study found that the inclusion of spectral data reduced the root mean square error of validation (RMSEV) and improved the correlation between actual and estimated ABCS compared to using only days in milk (DIM) as a metric. The performance of the neural network using DIM and morning spectra only was found to be robust across different strata of farm, parity, year of sampling, and breed. Therefore, the mid-infrared spectra of milk coupled with machine learning techniques can be used as a reliable metric to estimate ABCS in cows. The study did not mention any specific limitations or boundaries on how far this metric can go in estimating ABCS.

instruction: How does the use of mid-infrared spectra coupled with machine learning techniques compare to traditional methods in accurately estimating ABCS in cows losing body condition score at the fastest rate?
Output:
The use of mid-infrared spectra coupled with machine learning techniques has been found to be more accurate in estimating ABCS in cows losing body condition score at the fastest rate compared to traditional methods. The study found that including spectral data in the model reduced the root mean square error of validation (RMSEV) and improved the correlation between actual and estimated ABCS.

Specifically, when using all 305 days in milk (DIM) data, the neural network (NN) model using both morning and evening spectra along with DIM achieved the lowest RMSEV (0.96 x 10-3 BCS units) and the strongest correlation (0.82) between actual and estimated ABCS. When using the 120 DIM data, the NN model using DIM and either morning spectra only or both morning and evening spectra together achieved the lowest RMSEV (0.98 x 10-3 BCS units) and the strongest correlation (0.87) between actual and estimated ABCS.
